key_points: A cold snap in Texas is expected to increase gas prices by 10 cents to 20 cents in Rockford and nationwide.
The cold has affected oil production, with 20% of the nation's refining capacity down.
All 254 counties in Texas were under a winter storm warning, bringing freezing temperatures.
11 refineries in Texas and one in Kansas have partially shut down due to the cold.
COVID-19 travel restrictions lifting has already caused an increase in gas prices due to rising demand.
The average price of gas in Illinois is currently $2.77 per gallon, up from $2.48 last year.
The increase in gas prices is also attributed to the annual switch to summer-blend gasoline.
Gas prices in Rockford could reach an average of $3 per gallon by Memorial Day.
Refineries may take up to two weeks to return to full service after the cold snap.
Gasoline demand and prices may continue to rise into March and April.
spokespersons: Patrick DeHaan (Head of Petroleum Analysis, GasBuddy)
